title: A diagonal arm end for the Rostock Max to fit a "sturdy stake"

description.text:
This took a few tries, but these rod ends fit well in the end of a chopped off "sturdy stake" from Lowes/etc and fit well around an all metal U-joint for the Rostock Max. It was designed in OpenSCAD and those SCAD files are included, if you wish to modify this for something else.  
Backstory: My Rostock Max had a diagonal arm snap due to something stupid I did. I did not want to buy a new set from them, so I bandaged one for now using a sturdy stake and went on to design a more permanent replacement.  
0.8oz for my diagonal rod assembly before gorrilla glue.  
0.3oz for the Original (the new sturdier version is surely heavier) SeeMeCNC diagonal rod.  
I could probably trim some weight off by removing the plastic from the outside of the sturdy stake and spray painting it black.
The picture shown is an old picture from an earlier version.

Print some of these out and cut up some "sturdy stakes" from Lowes or some other place. Place the sturdy stake into the hole. If you do not cut it to the right length, you will need to adjust the firmware for the "radius" till your printer does not have the printing plane bend up or down in the middle of the print bed vs the outside of the print bed. Good luck there.  
These sturdy stake based arms should be alot sturdier than the original arms. Be careful not to bend the axles though or you may need to get some more axles. If that happens, maybe the 1/8"x6" (3.2mmx152.4mm) aluminum round bar (item 884465 from Lowes may work after sticking it in a drill/dremel and using sand paper on it.  
Make sure brim is turned on or you might not have enough bed adhesion.  
You may want to at least drive some nails (straight) into some scrap wood for the holes on the rod ends so you can make sure they are the right distance apart when you glue them.  
Oh yeah, if you only see 6 in the picture, you will want to print 2 sets of the plated version or plate 12 of the normal ones.
For removal, I found that when you have the tube painted black you might be able to heat the tube with a lighter while holding it in a large binder clip and then try to ease it out. If it stretches, you heated it too much and you need to let it cool. I had also removed some with a drill bit to melt the part with friction, but you really have to be careful not to damage the tube that way. Perhaps mounting the rod end with a screw through the tube would be better, but I have not tried it.

comments.text: Redesigned this to no longer use the cap from the Griffon delta printer. It seems that was the wrong end cap the the sturdy stake. I know the delta arms just fit though, so I am using a peg design.

description.text: When my fiance Melissa and I started planning our wedding last September we knew it wasnâ€™t going to be cookie cutter. We decided to include some personal additions that we just couldnâ€™t get elsewhere to make the day our own and at the same time save money. Hereâ€™s one example. Instead of buying bouquets for the wedding we decided to use our combined talents to create something that was not only skirted the norm but would also last quite a long time. We combined 3D printed parts from my Makerbot and crocheted flowers to create a rather unique bouquet for the bridesmaids. The model has a few internal faces and throws a couple errors when sliced but prints without any real problems. Good for Valentines Day, birthdays, anniversarys, and who knows maybe even other Maker weddings. More information and additional photos are available in this blog post: http://thenewhobbyist.com/2012/10/making-a-wedding-flowers/

description.text: I decided to make a clip for my work badge. This file prints with 1 print and includes the key ring.

Hey guys,
here is the project i'm actually working on, it's an mutlicopter "kit" design to be easily made with a simple 3D printer (even though most of the frame parts can be laser cutted too)
Just decide which kind of copter you want (hexa, quad) and print the parts you need!

Hey,
here is the beginning of my project, so expect this to change quite well! The main goal of this project was to create an easy-to-make hexacopter, because i think the world of multicopter i really great and i wanted to help people getting into it! However, most of the parts (except the main frame) can be reused for an octo or quadcopter without any changes. I will be designing the quadcopter main frame soon ;) Here are the parts to print (please double the scale on thickness, i made them 1.5mm wich is half of what is needed! i'll fix that as soon as possible!):

  • Main plate: print two of those, don't know the settings to put yet, as my printer is not working at the moment. If anybody wants to try or has an idea? (it needs a good infill to be strong enough)

  • Electronic support: print as much as you need of those. I basically use a 70*70mm scare holes mark to place all the components on the frame, because with the board i will be using (ardupilot 2.5), the holes for fixing it where just on the arms.. So i decided to make this hole mark for fixing everything on the main plates.

  • Battery support: As you can imagine, you will need one of those. I designed it to fit my turnigy 3S 4000mA battery, but feel free to modify it, and don't hesitate to send your file to me, i'll upload it on the thing for everyone!

  • Motor holder: print 6 of those, they are design to fit tightly on the arm so they won't move.

  • Motor holder plate: print 6 of those too. This ones are designed for the motors i use, the turnigy 2830-11, so the motor mount holes are 16 and 19mm. Once again, feel free to modify it!

  • Arm part 1: print 6 of those (need to check which infill to use though)

  • Arm part 2: print 6 of those (need to check which infill to use though)
    • And here are the vitamins:

  • for the arms, you need 12 M4*15 screws and nuts (nylon nuts are great!)

  • to attach the arms, you will also need 12 M4*25 screws, 12 nuts (nylon nuts could be fine to avoid the frame falling apart ;)

  • to attach the electronics and battery:

    • Battery straps
    • M3 screws, the lenght depends on your battery (which is supposed to be over the plate)
  • to fix the motors: 4 M310 screws and 4 M35 per arm (the last ones are for my motors, they depend of what motor you are using)
    • Thanks!

A 3D printable monitor button panel for the Porta-Pi arcade cabinet, a great little kit, fun to assemble and hack, and more fun to play. Note: Arcade cabinet kit not included :) (mine is Kickstarter version; delivered on time, too!).

I print both pieces in one plate, 20% fill and 4mm brim.  Fit is tight; you can download sources and adjust to suit (code is messy but parametric).   
Support in Slic3r doesn't seem to do much for buttons, but the free-air part is just a couple of layers high, so easy to fix quickly with a file after printing.  The little nubs are necessary though (switch faces not flat).  
The button cutout assembly is nicely designed and pretty forgiving of mistakes.  Proof: I glued it backwards (doh!) and it was pretty easy to fix.  Therefore what you see in my final assembled pics are different from the stock kit, but the STL is for unhacked panel (orange test print photo).  The innermost and outermost panels in the "sandwich" can be sanded across short edges by 0.5mm or so, to make fitting even easier.

title: Henry Bowen Anthony Fountain - Male Stone Face 1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Detail scan of a male face from the Henry Bowen Anthony fountain in Lippit Park at the head of Blackstone Boulevard in Providence RI. It is on the same fountain as these things: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32113
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32298 The fountain was installed in 1940 to honor Rhode Island U.S. Senator Henry Bowen Anthony, who served as a U.S. senator (1859 to 1884), Rhode Island governor (1849-1851), and publisher of The Providence Journal. Designed in a modern style by the Providence firm Jackson, Robertson & Adams, the fountain is the centerpiece of Lippitt Park, where Hope Street meets Blackstone Boulevard, near the Pawtucket city line It was scanned with 123D Catch and the raw scan is available here: http://www.123dapp.com/obj-Catch/Henry-Bowen-Anthony-Fountain--Mans-Face-1/872363 This scan is featured in the "Scanning in 3D" chapter of Getting Started with MakerBot : shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920026723.do? Also appearing in Make: Ultimate Guide to 3D Printing: http://www.makershed.com/Make_Ultimate_Guide_to_3D_Printing_p/1449357377.htm

I recommend printing the first file listed: "maleStoneFace1_Base.stl". It is already rotated with the flat side down. I have not printed this model yet, but I created it the same way I created the other stone faces from the fountain. 
The scan without the base is included, and is imported by the OpenSCAD file. If you want to modify the OpenSCAD, make sure the "maleStoneFace1.stl" is in the same directory. If printing the scan without the base, rotate the model so the flat side is facing down on the platform. 
Note: I just printed this on 10/2/2012 and for some reason this face turned out slightly larger than the other two faces from the same fountain (linked in the description).  I will have to see if I did something to scale it up pre OpenSCAD mashup or if it is actually larger in person.  I have marked this thing a "Work in Progress" to reflect this development.

description.text:
This camera case fits a Pixim Seawolf board camera. It weighs about 15g - substantially less than the stock case. The front and back are designed to be press-fitted and held with small squares of 3M mounting tape for quick assembly/dis-assembly while keeping the structure fairly lightweight. The back is open to allow maximum airflow to the board's heatsink.
The design was inspired by this PZ0420 camera case: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:159726
Suggestions for improvement are welcomed. Enjoy!
Update 7/6/2014: Flipped back plate STL and re-uploaded so users don't need to flip it in their printer host software.

Bill of materials:
Printed case parts
M3 screw (1)
M3 locknut (1)
Small 5x5mm squares of 3M mounting tape (4)
Instructions:
Print the parts and test fit the camera in the front part of the case. If there is a little bit of side-to-side play, that's fine. Cut 4 small pieces (around 5x5mm) of 3M mounting tape, and place them on the legs of the back part of the case. With the camera installed, press fit the back of the case into the front. The mounting tape should hold the assembly together snugly. if there is any jiggle, disassemble and add small amounts of mounting tape where appropriate to snug the fit (I didn't need to do this).
The holes are designed for a M3 bolt (25-30mm long or so) and a M3 locknut. You may need to use a 3mm drill bit to clean out the holes prior to installing the bolt.
Suggestions are welcomed. Enjoy!

collision free modification of x- and y-drives with the option to simulate; printing the parts from Open Scad files with the option of fixing the printers deviation when printing too small holes.

Hi guys,
This is my modification to GT2 belts and pulleys with 16 teeth.
The printing quality has improved a lot, so I could recommend you to dare this too.
I choose the 16-teeth pulleys fort he reason of better torque. The usage of 16-teeth pulleys for the idlers as well makes the drives run smoother than using only bearings fort the idlers.
For this modification it is necessary to make some changes to the locations of motors and idlers. It is not complicated for the x-axis; you just have to lower the x-motor position and the x-idler position for some millimeters. Solutions for that you find in different threads in the Velleman forum.
The best way to get the y-axis collison free with other parts ist o lift the complete y-axis drive up for an amount of 12 mm.
To check the situation and to be sure to have no collisions I made an OPEN SCAD file with all involved components, that lets you play with different parameters, so that you can check it all, before you disassemble your printer, after yo have printed the new components fort he modifications.
You will have to print the following parts:
1 y-motor holder
2 y-idler holders
1 y-clip bottom (to fix the belt to the heatbbed adapter, ABS is to be preferred)
1 y-clip top (with GT2-profile)
1 x-motor holder
2 x-idler holders (one hast o be mirrored
1 x-pulley holder base
I have made OPEN SCAD files for all those parts . They let you modidfy the dimensions, especially the diameters oft he bearings, because my printer does not print holes too small; To fix this issue I introduced a variable "dtol"Â, which gives to you the chance to get the exact diameter for the bearings. (If you know your printers deviation you only have to print the parts once).
Further informations you will find inside the OPEN SCAD File.
The file contains all modules (and corresponding informations) to create single components.
Just copy out the apropriate module, paste it into a new file and uncomment the lines at the end to get the module running. After pressing F5 and F6 you can do the STL export.
For the x-motor-holder there isno OPEN SCAD filed available, only a STL file.
it is a modificated file (thingiverse 253741 created by donboy --- thanks very much)
with following modifications (done with Blender on the STL file):
  • removed chamfer on frame mounting holes
  • increased distance between switch and motor block (for cable)

title: Shaft drive for my custom printer.

description.text:
This is one of those things that started out as one way and then literally (you'll get it later) went the other direction. My printer has a 8mm shaft with pulleys driving the Y axiz its a BIG gantry so two belts to keep it true I've had a geared drive on there for months and it works 100% but I felt its was a little noisy so I thought maybe as it printing quality is better than it was before I should redo the drive. I had originally made it to run with the herringbone gears as attached ( they are from a herringbone extruder that I modified from taking a hobbed bolt to a shaft) The herringbone gears are very particular about the messing of teeth and proved difficult. I had a few printed spur gears that I ended up using and that was what was on there for probably 7-8 months. For this I redesigned the holder. It takes a Nema17 motor and the attached herringbone gears will go in. You will need to ass a 608z bearing for the shaft its a bit of a push fit but sits nicely. The gears where still noisy and any imperfection in the gears had a tendency to catch. So I binned the idea and decided to try with a belt drive. a little more forgiving of tolerance and after printing a t2,5 that works well enough to make the aluminum pulley I got to replace it sit on my desk as spares I thought I would give a T2 gear a go After about 10 prints I finally had one that works well. I had to size it and added teeth till the belt fit snugly. You will also need to invert the motor in the firmware as it goes in the same direction as the motor not opposite as it does with gears. (get it now :-) It works well and is much quieter, steps reduce from the gear setup. It wont be something many would need but maybe there is someone who needs this to get their setup working. If you want to see more and how I create prints and 3D designs like this check out my YouTube channel.
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCSHUc93NXGwBacoIDDqPU2w

The herringbone gears dont need to be printed they are included as they where part of the original design. You will need a drive pulley for the motor T2 to match the driven pulley Think mine is a 20t You will need a small t2 belt (ultimaker)
You will need a 608z bearing for the shaft and you're on your own for a holder for the other side of the shaft but essentially something to hold another bearing in place. There are different screw holes you can pick what you need.

This is a full scale surfboard model, broken into 53 pieces and arranged on 14 plates for printing. The board design is the default thruster shape from the open source, GPL'd surfboard design software BoardCAD:
http://boardcad.com/ I started to print the first plate in ABS, but canceled it half way through because it was warping and cracking. I'm posting this to get some help with experiments with different materials and slicing settings. I'd like to see a pretty thin surface and minimal internal structure - as minimal as it can be to hold the shape when assembled and put up on the glassing stands. If you get all the parts from plate 1 printed nicely and fitted and glued together, let us know how you did it. Thanks! By the way, we don't imagine that 3D printing is a practical or efficient way to produce surfboards. My interest here is to explore efficient internal structures for surfboards. I'd like to see a cell/network type structure like bone, with varying density. There's no "bone" infill choice yet in slicing software yet that I know of, but I'm sure there will be soon. Maybe you can figure a way to approximate that by hacking current options. At the very least, it would just be nice to be able to print these large parts accurately enough, without warp and cracks, to be able to assemble them and glass it. (If you and your bot village are able to print it, I'll be glad to assemble and glass it.)

comments.text:
While I'm not planning to print and assemble this particular model, I do print and assemble large models so I'll share how I do it successfully. Keep in mind that I'm using PLA, so your properties will vary.
For bonding, I mostly use West System products. I've found G-Flex epoxy to be the best way to bond PLA, but 105/206 works fine as well. I've also used 105/207 when I've wanted a clear, but it needs a larger overlap for the glue joint as it doesn't bond quite as well. I sand with 60/80 grit and wipe with acetone. I've bonded ABS together with epoxy as well (though not 3D printed parts) and found it easier to bond than PLA (though I use isopropyl alcohol instead of acetone for obvious reasons on ABS). Oh, I usually add some colloidal silica (406) to the epoxy to keep it from running, since it doesn't soak into the plastic like it does to stuff like wood and thus, tends to drip more easily.
For making parts line up correctly, I either create the parts with registration keys so they fit together (you have to make sure your printer is calibrated for whatever your clearances are or be prepared to do some sanding/filing to get a good fit) or print jigs for the parts to hold them in the exact position while the epoxy cures. I always sand the bonded model smooth after assembly to get rid of the joints. Oh, and I clamp them while bonding.
When using jigs, or making molds from an assembled part, I put on several coats of paste wax and spray with release agent (I've had good luck with Mann Ease Release 200). Since I'm using PLA, parts/jigs pop off pretty easily after the epoxy cures.
I'm not a surfer, so you'll have to take this part with a grain of salt, but personally, if I were going to print a surfboard, I would assemble the board and use it to make a fiberglass mold. I would then use the mold to make regular (I assume) fiberglass boards. The other option would be to print and assemble parts of a female mold and skip the fiberglass mold step. For many applications, I print a positive and use it to make a mold because I find it gives me a better parting line than printing a mold directly (and it's much easier to sand smooth for a good surface finish), but I wouldn't think that would be an issue in this case since you'd probably go over the final board with fairing compound, etc. Anyhow, the advantage is that it's a lot faster to wet out some fiberglass in a mold than it is to print and assemble a huge part, so you'll be able to bang out boards and still get the benefits of a CAD-styled shape.
Additionally, I tend to avoid plated sets of parts because if something does go wrong, you're out way more time and material. I usually print individual parts. Yes it does take more time and planning -- some of my parts take me weeks to print -- but results in less overall waste. I've also taken the time to get my printer really well calibrated and have the process down to where I get no curling, etc. It really really helps if you can print nearly perfect parts.
Well, hopefully you can get something useful outta that core dump. ;)
If you have any questions, please ask.
comments.author: grozny

comments.text: Why the hell would you use epoxy? Look, epoxy is hella strong but 3d printing materials generally (as they are plastic) have a better bonding method. You want to fuse them into one solid piece, not glue them. Get a solvent and do it the right way. It will be stronger in the end. (epoxy is strong but doesnt compare to the actual surface bonding strength as fusion does. Epoxy also breaks down in the sun after a few years, it occurs a haze and can become brittle and crack. (you may notice this on some types of pebble walkways) And being that this is a surf board, in this case epoxy is even worse. Pla is said to be biodegradable and that it breaks down under UV radiation, and this is true, but the time scale for this compared to epoxy is drastically longer. Plastic can take 100's to 1000's of years to break down, regardless if its organic or synthesized.
comments.author: grozny

comments.text: We do fiberglass laminations on surfboards with epoxy made for that purpose. Boats are made with epoxy. There are definitely different formulations with different performance characteristics, some probably not so great in the sun, others meant to be in the sun for decades.
comments.author: DevWolf

comments.text: I keep thinking I should give solvents a try. What solvent(s) have you used for bonding PLA? I've already got a whole setup for working with epoxy, so it was a natural first choice. It also fills small gaps, which is nice. I've never tried to use these parts as the actual parts mind you, only as an intermediate step between CAD and the actual part. The properties of PLA pretty much exclude it from pretty much any practical use I would have for it other than a model or casting plug.
comments.author: DevWolf

comments.text: Also, it would be cool to see one of your large object productions illustrated somewhere - maybe a thingiverse thing that's more about the process than the actual thing, or an instructible or something. You could push people's imaginations beyond their print envelope.

title: Kali Necklace
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Necklace that I created for my Kali costume. The skull was scanned with 123D Catch and then made into a bead using OpenScad. The bead that has three faces was created with an OpenScad file and was then cleaned up and smoothed out with MeshMixer. I used emmet's stretchy bracelet OpenScad file to create the texture for the beads. I messed around with it until I had the texture I wanted and then exported it as an STL and imported that into a seperate file. I suppose I could have written it all as code, but I didn't. Have fun with this, I sure did. Vote for this project in the instructables Halloween contest: http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-Kali-Necklace/

Print and string the beads together. For the depicted necklace I used:
  • 14 of the large skull beads
  • 2 of the large ribbed beads
  • 2 of the small skull beads
  • 4 of the small ribbed beads
  • a single 3 face bead at the bottom of the necklace
    • Note: The vampireSkull 0.2.stl file is not a bead, it is used to generate the skull beads in combination with the OpenScad file. I was in a hurry and ran out of time, so I just used the beads I had been prototyping and strung them together. I did not have enough white ABS, so I broke out the glossy white Krylon Fusion spraypaint. The gold beads were printed in red translucent PLA, then spraypainted gold. This necklace took about a week to prototype and print. I printed the large skull beads on my Replicator in either white or natural ABS with 13% infil and 0.25 layer height. Each large skull bead took around 3 hours and 20 minutes. All the OpenScad files will be uploaded soon! I am busy doing Halloween things, but will clean them up and post them soon. UPDATE: The skull bead OpenScad file has now been uploaded. Make sure to download the vampireSkull_0.2.stl file and save it in the same directory to change the size of the bead / hole through the bread.

description.text: Parametric OpenSCAD joint connectors. These can be used to create hinge connecting pieces that have anywhere from 0 degrees to 365 degrees of range of motion. I used a similar syntax to Tony Buser's Pin Connectors ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10541 ). At the moment the file is only somewhat documented, but I'm uploading a project soon that highlights how these can be used. The parts I've printed with this system snap-fit tightly together with no additional work. There is usually enough friction to the connections that hinges can be positioned or, with light sanding, swing freely. The included module, "joint_examples_with_descriptions_in_comments()" will create a set of example objects for you to try out.

• Specify parameters for joints
  • Print
  • Connect!

comments.text: I'm not sure the one with the round top is quite right. First, since the arms have no shoulders, there's no need for the top to be round.  Second, it doesn't look quite round on the inside (I haven't built it yet, but I loaded it into OpenScad and looked at it carefully. Third, even if the roundness was needed, it should not continue past the three o'clock position. That cutout makes the part weaker for no good reason (that I can see). Fourth, if the roundness was needed, then it ought to continue 30 degrees past the vertical , or to the one o'clock position.

title: Back Drop for FABSCAN by Ceb

description.text:
I think part of the problem with the scanning not getting a cloud result is the missing backdrop. Fabscan seems to require a backdrop in order to stop the lasers and create the solid line behind the object being scanned.
I will upload the images after I make this object. It requires 3mm screws to connect it all together. 20mm length screws are required for the connecting the assembled Backdrop to the Backdrop Sled.
The rest of the Backdrop should be able to be assembled with 12mm length screws.
I have included how to connect the backdrop as one piece.
I have uploaded the new connectors as the first ones did not fit. I was off a mm for the small and way off for the long one. Remember to put the pieces together, you will flip one of the top, one of the bottom and one of the long connectors during assembly.

remixed_from.author: rubinkingma
remixed_from.title: Legs for q450/F450  style bottom glassfiber plate

title: Shock-Absorbing Landing Legs for F450 / Q450 style Flamewheel Xframe Quad-copter Multirotor DJI
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Looking to BEEF-UP your quad a bit?! PUT a little SPRING in your multirotor's step with my radical shock-absorbing extension legs! Designed with the famously cloned q450/f450 flamewheel style X-frame quadcopter in mind. Looking for a project to use your leftover McMaster MK8 extruder mod springs on (Part# 9657K331).. WELL, look no further! This .thing is a bonafide REMIX.. a 2 .thing mashup.. heavily influenced by yet another, 3rd .thing. What you're looking at: chrismalyon's "Flamewheel F450 Extension legs", cut down to use as a mounting & pivot bracket as well as upper-spring perch..

  • rubinkingma's "Legs for q450/F450 style bottom glassfiber plate"..since these legs offer excellent support.

    • I personally didn't have the clearance in the frame's arches to use rubinkingma's legs 'as-was', due to wiring and shrinkwrap and whatnot.. thus I redesigned the fitment to suit my own machinations. If you like a larger footprint, or want to land with style on rugged, uneven terrain.. then here you go! A lovingly frankensteined model, all glued together with some fancy Blender 'magic' to resemble a GIANT MK8 extruder.
    The minimalistic mk8 being the INSPIRATION of this whole piece piece really. oh, & Camera gimbals also welcome! So enough rambling.. unless you're printing... then you'll be here on Thingiverse a while..
    Hope you enjoy!!

Should work on any copter using DJI-style arms. Uses extra 2 screw/nut pairs.
&of course
McMaster spring Part# 9657K331.. (though I'd wager there's a slightly firmer or slightly softer spring out there more suited to the task..) 1 m3x16 screw/nut will secure the brackets on the leg.
Then another longer m3 can be used to secure the pivot, though I recommend going slightly wider to prevent play at this joint. The second screw should be up to 1" in length. Remember.. Snug fit for the pivot.. piloting out the holes before hand is recommended if you go wider than m3. (press firmly by hand or heat your screw a little bit to avoid splitting layers) Also..depending on your model/clone of the 450 frame you may notice the fitment isn't totally sealed around the inner or outer edge of the clamp pieces due to varied leg thicknesses in manufacturing... This actually is a GOOD thing for universality of fitment in our case. Don't worry about it unless it's due to uneven spacing in the pivot we've added on. You'll want to keep that as close to centered as you can.

remixed_from.title: MakerDev Extruder Fan Mount for MendelMax

description.text:
A simple solution for mounting a 40mm fan on the RepRap Huxley X-carriage. I made this to help with small or fast prints, which would curl in the corners. Note: if you run the fan at too high speed, there is a risk that your bed will be cooled down and your prints will unstick. Make sure to supervise the first few prints and adjust fan speed accordingly!
Setting the fan to turn on at a higher height may also help.

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/7u8WvHSNGVv
Thx to all that shared their house projects.
I added specifics to assemble a palace like Palazzo Vecchio in Florence
Simple paper Clip. Get ready to get back in school.
this rings are made to wed

This is a very simple hinged clamp with catch. It is designed to attach something to a strap (or other flat thing) up to 54mm wide.  As an example, I have used it to mount something on my guitar strap.

Build your thing with this on it, or simply use glue to attach it after printing.  
Print the inner and outer pieces separately.  You will need to print with a very small amount of support on both for the hinges. Remove the support and file the hinge surfaces flat so that they mate cleanly.  Drill out the hole in the center of the hinge with a small drill bit (I think a 5/64 should work), and insert a short piece of 1.75 mm filament.  Heat and mushroom the ends of the filament so it can't fall out.

This is just an idea. I don't know how feasible it is, or whether it's worth building or calibrating. In fact, I don't know almost anything about it...
It's a somewhat different 3D gantry design based around a tetrahedron. There are three axes, belt-driven or what-have-you, and each is connected by a sarrus linkage to the end platform.
I like it because it's extremely stable (tetrahedron) and every axis is exactly the same.
However, (1) it needs complex maths, (2) there's a large footprint, and (3) nobody's actually tried it.
Any thoughts?

1) Make it more of a tetrahedron instead of a right-angled pyramid thing.
2) Design actual files.
3) Print and assemble.
4) Be astonished (hopefully) at amazing stability and resolution!
(As for the OpenSCAD file, open and animate it at around 20 FPS, 180 steps)

comments.text: You're right; it kind of is like the Rostock. There is a smaller printing area (it would get larger as you lessened the angle between the axes - right now it's 90 - Rostock is at some infinite zero angle), but, because of the shape, it would hopefully be more stable.

title: Pibow Enclosure for the Raspberry PiÂ® Model B
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is an enclosure for the Raspberry Pi constructed from 9x 3mm layers of appropriate material.

Each layer should be approx 66mm by 99mm by 3mm thick when cut. Black and Green lines are essential cuts Orange lines are convenience cuts for better material release Red and Cyan lines are etched areas, but may be 'kiss' cut for speed The thin GPIO release section on layers 5 and 6 may warp during cutting under excessive laser heat.
Practice makes perfect. This design may change as the design for the Raspberry Pi is refined and updated. You can buy the case direct from us at http://pibow.com to support our work, and the development of future projects. We've released this design under CC BY-NC-SA so those with access to tools can make their own Pibow and learn from the design to make exciting new things themselves. We've gone for non-commercial for now to protect our business from clones. Yes, we know we're not hardcore enough :)

description.text: Replacement jet for a Hozelock sprayer, when you like me leave it out in the winter, and it gets destroyed by the frost.

You might want to print the v2 file instead, it's beefier around the top, so it should hopefully last a bit longer.  
The thread can be tricky to print, so start out by printing the Threadtest STL, until the thread comes out nice. I had to go down to 0.1mm * 0.5mm layers, not to get stringing.  
Lube the inside where the o-ring is riding with Vaseline.

description.text:
Okay, enough practical things for my cubicle walls. Now it's time to mount my Serenity shuttle figurine (see picture), from Universal Studios, so it's flying over my cubicle wall.  
It comes with a base which is just a flat platform with a 3mm-wide rod sticking up, and there's a small hole in the bottom of the ship, canted at an angle, so the ship seems to be flying and banking.  
To move this to a cubicle mount, I'm just printing a bracket with a hole in it the right size to fit a nail about the right thickness -- the closest I had was about 3.3mm wide, so I drilled out the ship's hole slightly larger. There's an inset for the nail head, and I've filed down the point of the nail with a Dremel moto-tool just for safety, though it'll be in the ship so that's just an excess of caution.  
The same technique could be used for many spaceships, planes, or other figurines.  
Redesign because the last one didn't hold securely enough.

Find a crew. Find a job. Keep flying.  
And if you print one, please post an I Made One picture. (Why does almost no one do this? I've had thousands of downloads of scores of designs and only one picture posted by anyone but me.)

author: mikebattaglia

title: Window blind cord or chain hook

description.text: A simple hook for stopping blind cords from dangling loose, either as a replacement for existing broken hooks or as an addition if you don't have them already.

I simply printed my hooks using brown PLA without supports. The lines you see in the photo are the infill patterns which are visible as the PLA I used is slightly transparent.  
I have included an STL file with a mirrored pair as sometimes the bed contact can change the appearance slightly cosmetically and if you have two hooks back to back it's nicer to have the look identical.  
I've also included the 123D Design files for those who would like to make changes.

author: SlayerBill

description.text: The original build would have taken too long to print for a next day present, so I rummaged the garage and found an unused standard pvc water pipe. 50cm long , 11cm diameter. With this as a base for a lighthouse I only had to print the top section(s), some windows a door and the housenumbers of course.

Yoe need:
  • a pvc waterpipe 11cm diameter
  • a waterpipe endcap (optional)
    • I spray painted the pvc pipe white, and found a rest of adhesive red lamination sheets I made the red rings of. Then I printed
    1x rail
    1x torch
    1x roof and hot glued them together, and hot glued them on the wider top of the pipe. 3x windows
    1x door the inner part of these matches the diameter of the pipe, I printed them standing upright, and hotglued them to fitting places of the lightouse. (note: I cut the upper part of the windows because they came out too cutesy for my taste) x housenumbers.
    I printed mione flat so they dont follow the curve of the pipe, because I liked the look better. They are not included in the download, but super simple to create. Of course you can buy ready done housenumbers and glue them to the lighthouse. stability.
    I filled the pipe halfway with pebblestones and closed the lower end wit a fitting endcap I had around. Just putting it over a 2L waterbottle does the same job.

description.text:
i made a "mascot" for BAS - we printed it out and distributed it at Expo Chicago in September. Enjoy! :D info about BAS: Founded in 2005 by Duncan MacKenzie, Richard Holland, and Amanda Browder, Bad at Sports ([email protected]) now features over 20 principle collaborators and is a weekly podcast, a series of objects, events, and a daily blog produced in Chicago, San Francisco, Detroit and New York City that features artists and â€œart worldersâ€ talking about art and the community that makes, reviews and participates in it. [email protected] can be tricky to describe: it acts as a curious investigator, an archivist, oral historian, and occasionally as a provocateur. We produce content that lies somewhere on the venn diagram of art, journalism, media, intellectualism, and â€œthe naughty bits.â€ We represent artists and their art world through an archive that is text, audio, physical, ephemeral, historical, and constantly evolving through ongoing and unique projects.
Bad at Sports has â€œdone stuffâ€ with apexart in New York City, the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago, Baer Ridgeway, NADA Art Fair, Open Engagement and many others. We share collaborators with Art Forum, Art Practical, The Chicago Tribune, Chicago Magazine, Art21, BUST magazine, Proximity Magazine, Modern Painters, Beautiful Decay Magazine, Art in America and numerous other publications. Our podcast has included approximately 400 interviewees/co-conspirators including Kerry James Marshall, Jeff Wall, Larry Rinder, Peter Saul, Liam Gillick, Mary Jane Jacob, Chris Ware, Tania Bruguera, Jeffrey Deitch, James Elkins, Meg Cranston, Carol Becker, and Polly Apfelbaum.
Bad At Sports has been a lot of different people but is currently Brian Andrews, Mark Staff-Brandl, Amanda Browder, Stephanie Burke, Terri Griffith, Richard Holland, Christopher Hudgens, Claudine Ise, Duncan MacKenzie, Patricia Maloney, Sarah Margolis-Pineo, Nicholas Oâ€™Brien, Caroline Picard, Abraham Ritchie, Tom Sanford and Abigail Satinsky.
If you are interested in contributing content to the program, please contact us at [email protected]
http://badatsports.com

title: Filament guide for Printrbot Simple 2014 with wooden extruder.

description.text:
I know there are plenty of these around, but they are often specific to different generations of Printrbot Simple.
This is for the Simple 2014 with wooden extruder.
I believe Printrbot, changed from 1/4 inch to 6mm, at some stage, and so things just don't line up.
See the pictures with head on view, into the extruder. You can see the feed is over to the left.
This guide feeds the filament directly to the geared wheel and bearing, giving it no chance to buckle. It has a chamfer on the bearing wheel side to allow it to get as close as possible.
This is a remix of a file called FIX.STL. You can see it in one of the pictures, it's brown, and held in with a bit of cable tie.The trouble was with a forward movment in the Y-axis, the guide would often get pulled out.
This guide also addresses that problem as it's screwed down. You could tape it if you prefer.
It just pops in. Screw or tape down.

comments.text: The "fix.stl" file is here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:285680http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...

I got annoyed by a couple of damaged or warped filament spools I have that wouldn't work with my other various rollers, so I designed this instead. Uses plain skateboard/inline bearings (608) and is sized for the spools I have around, but can be altered for other bearings and dimensions. I made the "hub" fit the smallest-diameter spool I had (about 15mm diameter center hole), and then did spacers to fit other dimensions. Uses pins.scad from this library to hold the bearings:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10541

Print a "hub" part with the center diameter to match the smallest spool you have. Attach bearings to the pins, they may require some filing down to fit depending on your printer (it is fairly tight). You may need a track for it to run on, depending on the surface.
Just print spacers for whatever various spool diameters you have (or just more "hubs" with different sizes). For spacers smaller than 30mm (or less than 10-15mm more than the hub diameter), the "small" spacer (solid, no spokes) makes more sense.

title: Nikon D700 flash light diffuser for the built-in flash

description.text:
Most flash diffuser products do not work because all they do is soften the shadow edges but the shadows are still present. This is because shadows in photos are created due to the light source (the flash) and the lens are not aligned, and all those flash diffuser products do is soften the light but do not change its path. This diffuser works because it changes the light path by bouncing it off of the ceiling or side walls resulting in the light falling behind the object which completely eliminates the shadows. This flash diffuser is designed for the Nikon D700 DSLR--it might works for similar Nikon cameras such as the D800 but I don't know for sure. For best results: Increase the flash output and/or ISO because the light bounced off of the ceiling and side walls loses its intensity resulting in underexposed photos so you will need to compensate for this by increasing the flash output and/or ISO. -This flash diffuser was designed so the weight is not carried up by the flash assembly springs but by the more rigid hot shoe.
-It does not reflect light back toward the photographer’s eyes or in any other unintended direction.
-It allows the light to be reflected off of any surround surface (ceiling, side walls) in any camera orientation because it rotated freely 360 degree.
-It does not create hard light/shadow lines on the background surface.
-It’s light, small, durable and professional looking (looks much better than a mirror angled in front of the flash!)
-It does not interfere with the camera operations (such as focusing, lenses, or focus assist light).

title: vent cup holder VW polo + slim cup edition

description.text:
first remix is about better fit to vent crate, so lower support beams are located just a tad higher. this allows better tilt, and more vertical position of cup, while bottom of holder still leans on vent hole edge for improved stability.
It fits VW polo 6n 1996 vent layout perfectly. another remix is about higher and slimmer thermal cup, or 0.5L PET bottle . i've noticed cup and bottles designs very a lot so i've included blender file - to allow anyone adjust height of upper holder .
be carefull to not rise the upper holder too high - be certain bottle is still secured even when it's bottom falls out of bottom stand. also a little bit of rattle is better than too snug fit, as it's annoying to lift whole holder along with cup and it can waste unnessesary seconds. Ofcourse stay safe and NEVER drink while driving! pull over, or use long timed intersection lights. @ just 50km/h you pass ~14m in 1s eye blink! EDIT: after almost year of use i've noticed ABS-like any other rubber compound - is prone to aging due to exposure to road-borne ozone.
If you want to make your cup holder survive longer without becoming brittle , try to coat it with acrylic lacquer, and/or use better cabin filter .

author: curious_pl

description.text:
The Extruder controller on my MakerBot has been erratic lately by shutting down during prints. I read on the MakerBot wiki (http://wiki.makerbot.com/cchb1) for the Heated Build Platform, that getting air flowing over the Extruder controller pcb will almost always keep it from shutting down.
I designed a low profile enclosure that mounts a 40mm by 40mm 12VDC sleeve bearing fan at the side of the Extruder pcb. This side mount design provides reasonable air flow over the board while maintaining access to the reset button and terminals which are not easily accessible with a top mount design.
I have uploaded the STL, G-code and SolidWorks assembly (.zip) files. With the uploaded G-code files, the total build time is approximately 47mins (24 mins for the funnel and 23mins for the fcover).

The assembly comprises of two parts to be printed on a 3D printer, four M3 nuts and four M3 by 25mm bolts.
Print the 3D parts, assemble and mount on top the controller pcb as shown in the photos. You can then run the fan wires to the fan pins on the controller board or run them directly to a 12V supply line (yellow & black wires) on the power supply. Note: Remove the standoff nuts directly below the extruder pcb. This will provide sufficient clearance to fasten the fan mount.

I found lots of tiny ants inside one of my beehives, they came marching up one of the corners of the hive where it rested on the support rack. To stop them, I designed this two-part stand where the lower part is filled with vegetable oil, creating a tiny moat which the ants (hopefully) can't cross.
Since ants aren't picky about finish, I printed with .5 mm layer thickness. I filled the tiny moat with acetone (its ABS, obviously) for 30 secs just to make sure any leaks were clogged up.

title: Ultimaker mount for Heavy Duty Spool

description.text:
This is a mounting for the Ultimaker to fit the Heavy duty printable filament spool, thing thingiverse.com/thing:10219. It attaches to the back, left, top frame bolt. It also has a printed thread cap to make it easy to change spools. The spacer not only allows the spool to sit away from the frame but you can also just print a different size for other spool types, there is also a shorter version to mount 2 spools. 02.11.12: Updated mount to fit rod better
09.11.12: Added a holder for filamant shipped with spools, there is also a longer rod to hold these fat spools, both plastic and cardboard
16.12.12: Some have issues with reel hitting motor, made it longer by 50mm to increase clearance. Would be helpful if someone could confirm this fixes the problem. Listed as Fluxline_Spool_mount_V2.stl
02.04.13: Some had issues with some filament spools hitting the extruder. I have added a new, V3 spool mount that shifts the rod more the side giving about as much clearance as you can have.

• Print the parts:
    ---- http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10219 or http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12175 (not actually tested this one).
    ---- The mount is printed on its side with a bit of support.

  • bolt the rod to the back of the mount, using countersink screw or bolt is best.
  • slide spacer over rod
  • remove back, left top bolt of frame, slide hook of mount over frame aligning holes and replace existing screw with 20mm. Best to carve out a bit of countersink on the printed mount depending on what type of bolt you replace it with.
  • Put on a spool with filament and secure with cap.

description.text:
This is a hotend holder for Rostock printer with 4mm OD bowden tube clamp. It fits J-Head hotends (and other hotends with 16mm OD).
It uses M3 screws instead of M4 to mount to the platform.

Print without support material. There's a thin celling in the hotend hole that needs to be cut through to open the squeeze gap and bowden hole. Use 2x M3x16 (or 20) bolts + nuts to secure the hotend and another 2x M3x20 bolts to mount to the platform. You will need to point a small fan at the hotend body so that the heat from the hotend doesn't soften the mount.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

This is a spool holder to use vertically. It requires mounting to a vertical surface and spins onf two 608 bearings. The spool-holder is removable and sits in the base using a key system so that one can change it out depending on the size of the filament spool being used. Designed for use with the I.S.A.A.C. 3-D printer shell (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:334685)

1.) print all parts + two 608 bearings, four 1/4' bolts, two M3 screws and some M8 threaded rod  
2.) Place bearings in the two bearing holes in the mount and Attach the mount to the back of the vertical surface using four 1/4' bolts, facing away from your printer.  
3.) place the mount cap on the mount and secure with two M3 screws.  Now yiou should be able to place the M8 rod in the mount.  it should rotate freely and not fall backwards due to the presence of the mount cap.  
4.)Screw the Spoolholder base onto the threaded rod so that is is approx 1/2 cm from the vertical surface.  The snug fit on the threads should allow it to spin on the bearings and not move about the threaded rod.  
5.) finally, screw the spoolholder down the threaded rod towards the spoolholder base.  When they are close, fit the triangular protrusion on the spoolholder into the groove in the spoolholder base.  This should secure the two pieces into the same rotation.  
6.) to change the spool holder simply unscrew it from the threaded rod and screw on a differently sized holder.

The lubemount is meant to hold the lube for the smooth rods in a Prusa i2 The pliers holder holds two small pliers or snippers. The screwdriver holder...holds screwdrivers! All can be affixed to a surface using M3 bolts Meant for use in the Isaac 3-d Printer Case (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:334685)

description.text: a work in progress with a stimulating array of possibilities

title: I.S.A.A.C 3-d Printer case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a work in progress. Any feedback is appreciated I.S.A.A.C. has everything you need to improve the functionality and safety of your 3-d printer (designed for Prusa i2). It stands for Intrepid Solid Asset Accumulating Construct (probably). includes;
-smooth, variable diameter spool holder
-holder for your tools (screwdriver, pliers, lube, ect.)
  • waste bin for plastic threads and bits
    -opening door to print bed
    -latching back panel for easy access repairs
    -Super awesome robot aesthetics!
    • I made mine from MDF and printed parts, but any material may be used. The dimensions for the 1/4" MDF piecesare included in the files. Additionally, I used metal hinges for the front and back doors, but I intend on designing printable versions in the future. Further, M3 screws can be used for all the small fasters and 1/4" bolts for all the large ones.

1.) print all parts and cut out all paneling.  
2.) Use the clamps to attach all of the panels together as shown in the pictures section.  I found the best way is to drill as you go; place a clamp against a part, drill the holes, bolt the clamp on, and then line the assembly up to a new panel and then drill those holes.  
3.) Place bearings in the two bearing holes in the mount and Attach the mount to the back of the vertical surface using four 1/4' bolts, facing away from your printer.  
4.) place the mount cap on the mount and secure with two M3 screws. Now yiou should be able to place the M8 rod in the mount. it should rotate freely and not fall backwards due to the presence of the mount cap.  
5.)Screw the Spoolholder base onto the threaded rod so that is is approx 1/2 cm from the vertical surface. The snug fit on the threads should allow it to spin on the bearings and not move about the threaded rod.  
6.) finally, screw the spoolholder down the threaded rod towards the spoolholder base. When they are close, fit the triangular protrusion on the spoolholder into the groove in the spoolholder base. This should secure the two pieces into the same rotation.  
7.) to change the spool holder simply unscrew it from the threaded rod and screw on a differently sized holder.  
8.) now use hinges to attatch the font and back doors.  Screw the handle to the front door with 1/4" bolts.  
9.) use M3 screws to attatch all of the tool holders and trash bin to the side shoulder panels  
10.) Bolt the neck piece to the shoulder and run any electronics up through it into the head.  This is especially for smart LCD controllers.  
11.) use super glue or any adhesive for the aesthetics (mouth, antenna, letters, ect)  
12.) print! You are now protected and aided by your new robot friend!

author: SorinMS

description.text:
This a 3D scan of a bust of Napoleon from the Usher Gallery and The Collection in Lincoln in the UK. The marble bust was made in the 18th Century by Antoine Denis Chaudet and 3D scanned by Oliver Laric in 2013. I decided to make the scan hollow and cut it in 2 pieces to save material and time. I filled the printed halves with plaster (gypsum) to add weight. After priming and painting it black I used a wax to make it look like antique gold. The original file and info can be found here:
http://lincoln3dscans.co.uk/napoleon/ http://www.3dwp.nl
In the files you can find the original solid STL (NapoleonBustSolid.stl)  that I have scaled up and touched up a bit. I cut it in two and made it hollow, these are the two other files.

We have designed this model Ferrari 458 kit that you can print and assemble with moving wheels. Http://gromfrog.com

Just print all of the main body parts: Ferrari part 1.stl
Ferrari part 2.stl
Ferrari part 3.stl
Ferrari part 4.stl
Ferrari part 5.stl We recommend using a raft with a low infill around 10%. We recommend using support on Ferrari part 5.stl as there is a overhang that will not print without support. For the wheels you will need to print the rest of the parts with a higher infill around 40% with raft and support. Once you have all the printed parts assemble the list of parts above by gluing them together and then place some glue in the slot and place through holes on model and insert other half and press firmly to attach wheels together. Once you have all the parts together you can then try and finish off the model if you like with sand paper or together materials.

This is a portable laptop cart for schools, built to solve the problem of the standard Bretford carts not moving in and out of buildings, over bumps easily.  It is both difficult to move them since they are so heavy and dangerous (we even had one tip over!).  
The chassis for it is the All-Terrain Radio Flyer Wagon.  It pulls pretty easily and carries 18 computers.

Acquire a Radio Flyer wagon.  We built ours out of poplar and plexiglas.  Use what works.  Poplar is nice since it doesn't scratch the computers, and its pretty inexpensive.
This is a work in progress!  We made a lot of the design decisions on the fly and so it has changed a bit from the original sketch up drawings.   I plan to update the drawings soon.
I plan to install the power adapters in the bottom area of the cart so that we can charge the computers in it as well.

description.text:
This is a remix.
Please do not tell me I stole this, I am referencing the source file.
All I did was take it, chop it up into different petals and put it back together as a multipart rose for dual prints in dual colors. Then I share that with you folks.
So please be thankful and not hateful.
I offer no warranty or technical support.
Please don't hate me if you can't figure this out yourself. Skill level required: 6

First of all, skill level required is 6 out of 10.
If you have ANY questions for this rose, then your skill level is less than 6. The ONLY technical support I offer on this object is the following:
I made this 75% scale.
2 shells,
50% infill. I used makerware for each part, imported one at a time, selecting "keep position" for each so that they import in their respective position and do not move to some unknown Z level.
After importing ALL parts plus the bottom, I selected ALL objects and moved them all to be flat on the build plate. If you cannot do this, save this object and other dual prints for a later time when you have more experience and learn the basics of 3D printing. Please enjoy, and please do not bother me if you are angry for your own technical shortfalls.

comments.text:
Yes I am condescending toward others because every time I try to help someone, point out something that needs fixing, or someone asks me for an "assembly file" (wth is that?) or claims the file is broken, I get annoyed dealing with stupid rude people on the internet.
In time you will notice that most people can't figure anything out on their own. Those that can, never really comment very often. The result is that it appears we have a bunch of fools trying to do 3D printing that don't have any skills.
Sorry if you were insulted.
Last time I made a remix, some idiot accused me of stealing someone elses design after I clearly uploaded it as a remix and linked the org design. Very sad.

comments.text: An assembly file is file were all the part files (your petals) are put together to create the final design. Here you would probably make two different assembly files (one for each color then you would turn them into STL files). This way people that are not as skilled would be able to also use this and would just have to use two files instead of trying to properly line up all of the petals individually. For my 3D printer using more than two files on the build plate at a time causes a lot of problems.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I\'ve seen these in wood and aluminum.
I decided to try to do them in plastic on a Makerbot. Designed in Sketchup.

The intent is for the two hearts to be separate, but captive pieces.
The base is there to provide stability during the build process. It should be cut away after printing is complete.

description.text:
This is a simple test where we show how a MakerBot Replicator 3D printer can be paused so that a small plastic sphere (whistle pea) can be inserted into the whistle before the 3D printer closes up and seals the top.
We modeled this whistle based on Zaggo's popular http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1046 By Creative Tools

  • Home - Things - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Youtube - Instructables - Instagram - Flickr - Vimeo - LinkedIn

Check this video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G4QTAXEQEBs
  • Load the STL file into your 3D-printer software.
  • After the pea is completed pause your 3D-printer
  • Remove the pea
  • Insert it into inside of the whistle body
  • Resume the 3D-printing of the whistle to finish and enclose the pea
    Enjoy! :)

title: "V10" a redesign of the GRRF PRotos
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I designed a new Printer based on the GRR PRotos metal frame.
The intention was to remove all design weaknesses I found over the last 1000 hours print.... and it works more than perfect.
Replaced the wobbly 8mm stuff with stable 10mm linear guides for all axes.
Z axis is prepared with precise 8mm trapezoid thread
Special Cooling system for perfect PLA Printing fits for standard GRR Hotend.
enhanced Hotend version for E3D Nozzles and bigger Heatblock for rock solid extrusion temperature
special Extruder adapter for direct extruder with very easy Filament transporter.
optional a 5:1 gear Nema17 can be mounted but my experience is that the gear needs higher Voltage than 12V !! otherwise retract will cause huge trouble
fits also for all Hotends with 16mm mounting diameter.
The pictures are showing the rest :)
The printed Hand shows how precise it works - the diameter of the fingers is between 1.2 and 2 mm.. printed with a 0.4 nozzle !! Sorry but the parts are not for download but if you contact me I will make you an offer.

title: 50mm blower mounting system - Makergear M2 Z-axis cooler

description.text: I needed a compact way to cool my Z-axis stepper motor on my Makergear M2. I'm not sure if I really needed to cool it, but I wanted a way to cool it. The space available was not that great and I was faced with the prospect of creating a rather elaborate ductwork for a fan mounted off the printer. There are several on Thingiverse, but I wanted something easier. I was also looking for a fan I could power off a USB hub. That meant 5vdc instead of 12vdc. I found these on Amazon: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00EL938E6/ref=wms_ohs_product?ie=UTF8&psc=1 and they were exactly what I was looking for. The mounting setup I created is all friction-fit. Since it's laying on its side, I didn't need or want to mess with mounting hardware. I created a base, a grilled top and a solid top. I could certainly run the fan without the a top plate, but there's often pieces of filament and the occasional tool dropping down on the printer's base and I wanted to keep droppings from fouling or damaging the fan. The solid top has a bit more clearance to keep the intake airflow adequate. The grilled top sits a little closer to the fan. You could also invert the fan so the intake is on the bottom. An additional benefit is the fan pulls warm air out of the control box it's mounted beside, helping to keep the drive electronics a tiny bit cooler.

I generally print these with 2 perimeters and 20% infill.  They're not load-bearing, so you can probably use your favorite settings.  
The pegs - that fit inside the fan mounting holes - are sized to fit these blower fans just right - a tiny bit loose so they're easy to assemble and disassemble, but they should also hold if you mount the fan vertically (in some other location) instead horizontally.  It's possible that vibration might cause the fan to slip off when mounted vertically though it seems unlikely.  I'm sure you can figure a way to get them tighter if necessary.   
I've been mounting mine to my Makergear M2 base with scrapbook mounting tape (double-side sticky) because it can be easily removed,  I was planning on moving on to foam mounting tape, but the scrapbook tape has held well enough that I'll probably just leave it.

comments.text:
I'm sure tweaking the standard axial fan can and does improve performance, noise level, power consumption or whatever they are shooting for, and that's all well and good.
My question would be will they cool this extruder any better.
The ones you linked are designed to cool either computer cases or their component heat-sinks. None of mine have restricting shrouds. In fact just the opposite. Shrouds, if there are any, are designed to allow maximum air in and out. A constriction just kills air flow and designers know it..
I think it's possible that the small benefits afforded by the special, modified fan blade and / or frame shapes could be unduly impacted by a constriction and the result might be they will flow even less air than the ordinary everyday axial fan.
comments.author: Kulitorum

comments.text:
i hate to say it but no axial fan can develop much pressure even in free air. They are designed to move a large volume.
Centrifugal fans (blowers) are designed for pressure.
http://www.allelectronics.com/make-a-store/item/cf-403/12-vdc-120-mm-centrifugal-blower/1.htmlhttp://www.allelectronics.com/...
I hacked the one I use from a Harbor Freight 12V "car defroster"... maybe 55mm diameter ... brushless...and a very powerful air stream even when constricted by a funnel.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
This kind of fan is not able to create a very large static pressure, so it can't push any air through this type of funnel. It pretty much does the same as if you hold the funnel 5cm from your mouth and blow. No air is pushed through the funnel, rather it's blowing back in your face.
To make this work, you need a fan build for static pressure - that's like one in 100, so picking some random fan from a old computer won't do it.
Something like this will work: http://www.sanyodenki.com/archive/document/corporatedata/technicalreport/2005/TR20e_f_en.pdfhttp://www.sanyodenki.com/arch...
You can sometimes find this kind of fan in high quality rack-mount computer equipment like 40port switches and such.
This may also be okish: http://www.haltechtv.com/unboxing--review-archive/noctua-nf-a4x10-40mm-fan-written-reviewhttp://www.haltechtv.com/unbox...
Or this: http://www.performance-pcs.com/catalog/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=123&products_id=22537&zenid=33243d50667822473c3cf2705a958c2dhttp://www.performance-pcs.com...
Notice that all the fans I linked are 20mm+ thick.

This is a set of model atoms that can be connected together with flexible tubing to create molecular models. I've created them to assist me in my tutoring of high school students in chemistry. True, these can be bought in scientific book shops, but then they are incredibly expensive. In addition, you never get S+, O+, O-, and N+ to build ozone, sulfur oxides, nitrogen oxides and derived substances.  
With this set of drawings, you can print your own, you can freely extend your set if you need more, and with the added SCAD files you can even customize them.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1 mm layer size

Infill:

20%

Notes: 190 °C print temp, bed 55 °C with PLA

Print the atoms in different colours. In commercial sets, usually the following colours are used for the atoms:
  • C atoms --> black
  • H atoms --> white
  • O atoms --> red
  • Halogens --> green
  • N atoms --> blue
  • P atoms --> purple (but I used orange)
  • S atoms --> yellow
    • The difference with a commercial set is that this one also includes an aromatic C6-ring for your phenyl groups, some positive ions (sulfonium, oxonium, nitronium) and a negative ion (oxide). This enables you to also create O3, SO2, NO2, NH4+, etc. I used an Ultimaker (v1), and a print speed of 20 mm/s, wall thickness 1 mm, temp 190°C, bed temperature 55°C, but still, on the bottom side of the spheres, I have problems with curling edges. Maybe try lower bed temperature and lower print speed. Results may vary for different PLA qualities. I advise to use some support for the overhanging parts. The 'PlusMinus.stl' file contains very small pluses and minuses to print in either black or white. I used these to insert into the plus and minus signs on the ions, makes them stick out a bit more. Simple two-component epoxy resin can be used to permanently fix them in their places. It's a little fiddly and it will test your patience, but it looks great in the end. To complete the molecular modeling set, I used flexible hoses that can be purchased at a pet store or fish tank specialist. It's 3mm internally, which fits perfectly snug around the 3.2 mm pins. If you have hoses with a different diameter, it is easily adapted in the SCAD file (at the end, a 'pin' module is defined, change the pinradius to half the hose diameter + 0.1 mm). Create
  • short bonds, about 40 pieces of 2 cm
  • medium bonds, about 20 pieces of 3.5 cm (for double bonds)
    • Enjoy your molecule set.

This is a fan duct that can be attached over top of a fan to force air more towards the extruder tip. Potentially giving better PLA prints.
I always found that printing certain parts in PLA on the 3d touch can be messy (especially small, high res parts with large over hangs). I did some test prints and they turned out really good using the increased air flow and having it directed near the nozzle tip.
Even large flat PLA parts came out really well!

EDIT You no long need to move the limit switch. I added a pocket into the model that should clear the limit switch. Print Rev2 for that change. Edit Added Fan duct for front right position (I'm sure it can also be move to the left spot too). Tips on moving the limit switch:
http://www.bitsfrombytes.com/usd/forum/post/heated-bed-0?page=10#comment-36957
Also a link to a Thiniverse page with a printable mount and explanation
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26182 Step 1: Install aftermarket fans. They must be bellow 15mm so as it will fit and not crunch into the build platform.
-Here's an example of the fans I got. I tried to maintain the same specs that were on the stock fans (http://www.digikey.ca/product-detail/en/KD1206PHB1.(2).GN/259-1337-ND/1021186) This link is strange only works if you copy and paste the whole thing :P.
-The fans I got are powerful, main difference is the higher RPM. Which also increases the noise output. Step 2: Print part... with support (sorry).

comments.text: I've started a new design, inspired by yours, that snaps in. It's work-in-progress still. I need to design a deflector that snaps onto the open end of the duct (which means I'll need to add snap-on features to the existing duct design), to aim the airflow down toward the bed and the end of the extruders. I don't think making it in two pieces is a drawback when the goal is to make it printable without support and snap-on/snap-together friendly. I wonder if I need the deflector, but I suspect without it the additional airflow higher up on the extruders could cool them unfavorably. My new design attempt is at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:234868http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
comments.author: tetralite

comments.text: Cool design, I recently tried printing the PLA heart gears and I still get curling at the steep over hang area. I'll definitely give these a try. Did you print them in ABS? I found that if I print my fan ducts in PLA they tend to warp to the heat generated by my heated bed, but it looks like you don't have to worry about that.
comments.author: tetralite

comments.text: I don't know if mine works any better than yours, but I did notice on some prints with overhangs that the curling up seems to be reduced. I printed them in PLA, and yes, I don't have a heated bed. I might still try adding a clip-on piece to see if deflecting the airflow down a bit helps,

Inspired by the original design, we played around with Tinkercad and learned a lot. We could not fit the fabberworld.com spools on the original design even with the 32mm version of the top part. The V9 design is far from perfect, but it fits our needs. Feel free to alter and print it.

To make it enough solid, just print 80-100% infill. Print each part 1x and stick it together. Could even be glued together, or fixed with a cable tie or some tape if needed. https://tinkercad.com/things/9wMLyzReYQa-ultimaker-reel-holder-id-32mm-v9-arm-links https://tinkercad.com/things/5sGP2phQ4Rv-ultimaker-reel-holder-id-32mm-v9-arm-rechts https://tinkercad.com/things/aFQTKdKsuxu-ultimaker-reel-holder-id-32mm-v9-top

description.text: It says "I MADE THIS" which of course you totally did! This is a remix of my regular Xbox One, but in the white 2013 launch team/employee edition. More details here: http://davenunez.wordpress.com/2014/05/17/mini-xbox-one-employee-edition/ If you want a regular Xbox One, go here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:189071

Print body.stl and xb_bluray.stl in white, and the other two parts in black. Paint xb_bluray.stl silver, and press the parts together. Finally, print stickers.pdf onto self-adhesive paper, and stick them on! If you want a Kinect, get it from my regular Xbox One: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:189071

Geodesic, 36mm and 85mm diameter.
Now a full hemisfere, just print 2 times. Resize it to make bigger.
Add a lamp or leds inside.
Print or paint the pieces in different colors.
Easy to print, 1 plate the small and 2 plates the big. You can help me to do more things like this.
Buy my designs at pinshape:http://pinshape.com/users/27920-jsirgado
The OpenSCAD file is there, you can change all.

Created with OpenSCAD - Open source programmable CAD. You can change all parameters and create your own geodesic object. Mounting (parts):
1 pentagon at top.
5 hexagons in ring around the pentagon on top.
5 pentagons between the hexagons of ring.
5 hexagons between the pentagons above.
Glue all. Mounting (hemispheres):
Make 2 of them and glue the 2 hemispheres together.
